Module 9: Multiple Choice Questions

For students

Last updated: 24/10/2025 14:06

The questions are based on or inspired by the following references:

  • Berk & DeMarzo, Corporate Finance, 5th ed. (2020)
  • Brealey & Myers, Principles of Corporate Finance, 13th ed. (2020)

Q1.

Which of the following best describes financial distress in a firm?






‚úÖ B is correct. Financial distress occurs when a firm cannot fulfill its debt obligations or violates loan covenants.

Q2.

Which of the following is an example of an indirect cost of financial distress?






‚úÖ D is correct. Indirect costs include reputation damage and lost business relationships during financial distress.

Q3.

According to the trade-off theory, what determines a firm‚Äôs optimal debt level?






‚úÖ A is correct. The trade-off theory states that firms balance tax benefits of debt with expected costs of distress and agency conflicts.

Q4.

What is the primary reason why shareholders may favor riskier projects when a firm is highly leveraged?






‚úÖ C is correct. This is the classic ‚Äúasset substitution‚Äù problem‚Äîshareholders gain from upside volatility while debt absorbs losses.

Q5.

Which of the following best illustrates the debt overhang problem?






‚úÖ E is correct. In debt overhang, equity holders avoid financing new profitable projects as the benefits mainly accrue to debtholders.

Q6.

Which of the following is an example of an agency benefit of leverage?






‚úÖ D is correct. According to the free cash flow hypothesis, debt disciplines managers by reducing funds available for unproductive use.

Q7.

What does the signaling theory of debt suggest about firms with higher leverage?






‚úÖ C is correct. Under asymmetric information, taking on more debt can signal that managers are confident in future performance.

Q8.

Which of the following is NOT an assumption of Modigliani and Miller Proposition I in a perfect market?






‚úÖ A is correct. MM assumes perfect markets with no taxes, no bankruptcy, and no agency costs.

Q9.

Which of the following statements best describes asymmetric information?






‚úÖ E is correct. Asymmetric information occurs when managers know more about firm prospects than outside investors.

Q10.

According to the pecking order theory, firms prefer which sequence of financing sources?






‚úÖ D is correct. Firms use internal funds first, then debt, and issue equity only as a last resort to minimize information costs.

Q11.

What is the main reason that financial distress is more costly for firms with intangible assets?






‚úÖ C is correct. Intangible assets such as brand value or R&D have little resale value, making distress more damaging.

Q12.

Why might high leverage discourage managers from taking positive-NPV projects?






‚úÖ A is correct. This is the debt-overhang effect‚Äîshareholders may reject positive-NPV projects when gains mainly benefit creditors.

Q13.

What is an agency cost of equity?






‚úÖ D is correct. Agency costs of equity arise when managers act in their own interest rather than in shareholders‚Äô best interests.

Q14.

Which of the following statements best describes debt covenants?






‚úÖ B is correct. Covenants align shareholder and creditor interests by preventing actions that increase default risk.

Q15.

Which of the following is a potential benefit of leverage?






‚úÖ E is correct. Debt obligations force managers to generate cash flow and avoid wasteful spending, aligning incentives.

Q16.

Which of the following best explains the pecking-order theory of financing?






‚úÖ C is correct. The pecking-order theory prioritizes funding that minimizes asymmetric information costs.

Q17.

What is the ‚Äúfree cash flow problem‚Äù in corporate finance?






‚úÖ A is correct. The free cash flow problem arises when managers overinvest or misuse excess funds rather than returning them to shareholders.

Q18.

What is the primary cause of asymmetric information between managers and investors?






‚úÖ B is correct. Managers know more about firm operations and future performance than outside investors, leading to information asymmetry.

Q19.

Which of the following statements about financial distress is TRUE?






‚úÖ E is correct. Even without bankruptcy, financial distress can hurt relationships and damage long-term firm value.

Q20.

According to the trade-off theory, why don‚Äôt firms use 100% debt financing?






‚úÖ C is correct. While debt provides tax benefits, excessive leverage raises the risk and cost of financial distress.

Q21.

Why might managers be reluctant to issue new equity according to signaling theory?






‚úÖ B is correct. Under asymmetric information, issuing new equity may signal to investors that management believes the firm is overvalued.

Q22.

What type of firm is most likely to suffer large indirect costs of financial distress?






‚úÖ E is correct. Firms relying on reputation or intangible assets suffer more from lost confidence and relationship breakdowns.

Q23.

What happens when a firm violates a debt covenant?






‚úÖ C is correct. Covenant violations can trigger renegotiations, tighter restrictions, or acceleration of repayment.

Q24.

According to agency theory, why can leverage increase firm value?






‚úÖ A is correct. Debt acts as a disciplinary mechanism, limiting excess cash that managers might otherwise waste.

Q25.

What is a typical indirect cost of financial distress?






‚úÖ D is correct. Indirect costs include the loss of reputation, customer trust, and supplier confidence.

Q26.

Which of the following statements best describes the leverage ratchet effect?






‚úÖ B is correct. Once debt is issued, shareholders are reluctant to reduce it, since deleveraging mainly benefits creditors.

Q27.

How does high leverage affect management incentives?






‚úÖ E is correct. Required debt payments create pressure on managers to operate efficiently and focus on value creation.

Q28.

What is the main insight from the pecking-order theory regarding equity issuance?






‚úÖ A is correct. Firms avoid issuing equity unless necessary, as it may signal to investors that shares are overpriced.

Q29.

What is the main idea behind the trade-off theory of capital structure?






‚úÖ D is correct. The trade-off theory predicts that optimal leverage occurs where marginal tax benefits equal marginal costs of debt.

Q30.

Which of the following factors increases the likelihood of financial distress?






‚úÖ C is correct. Firms with volatile earnings face a higher probability of financial distress due to inconsistent cash flows.

Q31.

Which of the following best explains why debt can act as a disciplinary mechanism?






‚úÖ A is correct. Debt commitments limit managerial discretion and encourage efficiency through required cash payments.

Q32.

What is the primary purpose of restrictive debt covenants?






‚úÖ D is correct. Debt covenants protect creditors by restricting risky activities that might harm their interests.

Q33.

According to the pecking-order theory, why do firms prefer internal financing?






‚úÖ C is correct. Internal financing avoids negative market signals and the costs of external financing.

Q34.

Which of the following statements about agency conflicts is TRUE?






‚úÖ E is correct. Agency conflicts occur in multiple relationships‚Äîbetween owners, managers, and debtholders.

Q35.

Which of the following is an example of an indirect financial distress cost?






‚úÖ B is correct. Lost reputation and business relationships are typical indirect costs of financial distress.

Q36.

According to the free cash flow hypothesis, how does debt mitigate agency problems?






‚úÖ D is correct. Debt reduces discretionary funds and aligns managerial incentives with firm value creation.

Q37.

Which of the following describes an overinvestment problem?






‚úÖ C is correct. Overinvestment occurs when managers invest in unprofitable projects that increase their control or prestige.

Q38.

Why do firms with volatile earnings often choose lower leverage?






‚úÖ A is correct. Firms with unstable earnings prefer less debt to reduce the probability and cost of distress.

Q39.

Which of the following statements about asymmetric information is TRUE?






‚úÖ B is correct. Managers may prefer debt to avoid sending a negative signal to investors about potential overvaluation.

Q40.

Which of the following statements best summarizes the trade-off theory?






‚úÖ E is correct. The trade-off theory explains that optimal capital structure balances tax advantages with the risks and costs of debt.

Q41.

Which of the following best describes the underinvestment problem?






‚úÖ C is correct. The underinvestment problem occurs when shareholders avoid new investment since returns mainly benefit debtholders.

Q42.

Why can debt reduce managerial entrenchment?






‚úÖ E is correct. Debt pressures managers to perform efficiently, reducing the scope for entrenchment and wasteful behavior.

Q43.

Which statement is consistent with the signaling role of leverage?






‚úÖ B is correct. High leverage can signal managerial confidence about strong future cash flows.

Q44.

Which of the following is a direct cost of financial distress?






‚úÖ A is correct. Direct costs are explicit expenses incurred during legal or administrative processes in distress.

Q45.

Which of the following best describes the debt-overhang problem?






‚úÖ C is correct. Debt overhang discourages equity holders from investing in positive-NPV projects that primarily benefit creditors.

Q46.

Which of the following firms is most likely to use higher leverage?






‚úÖ D is correct. Firms with stable cash flows and tangible assets face lower distress costs and can sustain higher leverage.

Q47.

Which of the following statements about the pecking-order theory is TRUE?






‚úÖ B is correct. The pecking-order theory reflects financing hierarchy based on information asymmetry and cost of capital.

Q48.

What is the relationship between profitability and leverage under the pecking-order theory?






‚úÖ E is correct. Profitable firms often have sufficient internal funds and thus rely less on external debt financing.

Q49.

Which statement about financial distress is CORRECT?






‚úÖ C is correct. Financial distress damages reputation and stakeholder trust even if bankruptcy is avoided.

Q50.

According to the trade-off theory, what happens when a firm increases its leverage beyond the optimal point?






‚úÖ A is correct. Beyond the optimal leverage level, additional debt destroys value as distress costs outweigh tax benefits.

Q51.

According to the trade-off theory, what happens when a firm increases its leverage beyond the optimal point?






‚úÖ A is correct. Beyond the optimal leverage level, additional debt destroys value as distress costs outweigh tax benefits.

Q52.

Which of the following is a potential benefit of financial leverage?






‚úÖ E is correct. Debt obligations can discipline managers, encouraging efficient use of cash and avoidance of wasteful projects.

Q53.

According to the trade-off theory, when is it optimal for a firm to issue additional debt?






‚úÖ B is correct. Firms add debt until tax benefits are offset by the rising expected cost of financial distress.

Q54.

Which of the following firms is least likely to use high leverage?






‚úÖ D is correct. Startups with uncertain revenues face high financial distress risk and thus avoid excessive debt.

Q55.

Why might leverage create conflicts between shareholders and creditors?






‚úÖ A is correct. This is the asset substitution problem‚Äîshareholders may favor riskier investments once debt is in place.

Q56.

Which of the following is an example of managerial entrenchment?






‚úÖ E is correct. Entrenched managers act to preserve control even when takeovers could increase shareholder value.

Q57.

According to signaling theory, what does a firm‚Äôs decision to increase debt typically indicate?






‚úÖ D is correct. Taking on more debt signals confidence in future cash flows since managers commit to fixed obligations.

Q58.

Which of the following can be considered an indirect cost of financial distress?






‚úÖ C is correct. Indirect costs arise when distress weakens reputation, leading to sales losses and strained relationships.

Q59.

How can equity issuance create an adverse selection problem?






‚úÖ B is correct. Under asymmetric information, investors interpret new equity as a signal that shares may be overpriced.

Q60.

Why are firms with high intangible assets often less leveraged?






‚úÖ E is correct. Intangible-heavy firms face higher expected distress costs since such assets lose value in bankruptcy.

Q61.

Which of the following best explains why debt holders impose covenants on borrowers?






‚úÖ C is correct. Covenants restrict risky managerial behavior and protect creditors from value-reducing actions.

Q62.

How does leverage affect the incentives of equity holders in distress?






‚úÖ A is correct. When firms are highly leveraged, shareholders may prefer riskier projects due to limited downside exposure.

Q63.

Which of the following is an implication of the free cash flow hypothesis?






‚úÖ D is correct. Debt commitments force managers to use free cash efficiently, lowering agency costs.

Q64.

What does the pecking-order theory suggest about firms with large cash reserves?






‚úÖ E is correct. Firms with sufficient cash prefer internal financing to avoid signaling problems or issuance costs.

Q65.

Which statement best describes the trade-off theory of capital structure?






‚úÖ B is correct. The trade-off theory suggests firms weigh tax advantages of debt against bankruptcy and agency costs.

Q66.

What is a common outcome of information asymmetry in financial markets?






‚úÖ C is correct. Asymmetric information often leads to undervaluation of equity, reinforcing the preference for debt or retained earnings.

Q67.

Which factor increases the likelihood of high financial distress costs?






‚úÖ A is correct. Firms with volatile earnings face higher probability and cost of financial distress.

Q68.

What does the debt-overhang problem imply?






‚úÖ E is correct. Debt overhang leads shareholders to reject profitable projects when benefits mainly accrue to debtholders.

Q69.

Which of the following is a consequence of high leverage for equity holders?






‚úÖ B is correct. Increased leverage raises equity risk, leading to higher expected returns required by shareholders.

Q70.

Which of the following is a managerial action consistent with the agency cost of equity?






‚úÖ C is correct. Overinvestment in unprofitable expansion reflects agency costs when managers prioritize personal objectives.

Q71.

A firm has a 25% probability of entering financial distress. If distress leads to a loss of $60 million in firm value, what is the expected cost of financial distress?






‚úÖ C is correct. Expected distress cost = 0.25 √ó 60 = $15 million.

Q72.

An unlevered firm is worth 500 million. Adding debt creates a tax benefit of 40 million but expected financial distress costs of 10 million. What is the levered value of the firm?






‚úÖ D is correct. Levered value = 500 + 40 ‚àí 10 = $530 million.

Q73.

If a firm‚Äôs unlevered value is 800 million, the present value of tax shields is 60 million, and the expected cost of distress is 20 million, what is the value of the levered firm?






‚úÖ C is correct. VL = VU + PV(Tax Shield) ‚àí PV(Distress Cost) = 800 + 60 ‚àí 20 = 840.

Q74.

A firm plans to issue $150 million of 10-year debt at 8% interest. The tax rate is 25%, and the discount rate for the tax shield is 8%. What is the present value of the tax shields over the debt‚Äôs life?






‚úÖ Correct: B.
Annual shield = 150 √ó 0.08 √ó 0.25 = 3.0 million.
PV = 3.0 √ó [1 ‚àí (1 / 1.08¬π‚Å∞)] / 0.08 = $28.1 million.

Q75.

A firm‚Äôs probability of bankruptcy is 15%, and the estimated cost in bankruptcy is $120 million. What is the expected cost of distress?






‚úÖ D is correct. Expected cost = 0.15 √ó 120 = $18 million.

Q76.

If a firm‚Äôs debt provides a tax benefit of 5 million per year and the expected cost of distress is 1 million, what is the net benefit of leverage?






‚úÖ B is correct. Net effect = Tax benefit ‚àí Expected distress cost = 5 ‚àí 1 = $4 million.

Q77.

A firm‚Äôs value without leverage is 500 million. Debt adds 50 million in tax benefits but 10 million in expected distress costs. What is the firm‚Äôs value with leverage?






‚úÖ E is correct. Levered value = Unlevered + Tax benefits ‚àí Distress cost = 500 + 50 ‚àí 10 = 540.

Q78.

A firm has an unlevered value of 900 million. It expects to gain 60 million in tax shields from debt but lose 20 million to agency and distress costs. What is the value of the levered firm?






‚úÖ E is correct. Value = 900 + 60 ‚àí 20 = $940 million.

Q79.

A firm‚Äôs managers may waste 4% of firm value through poor investment decisions when leverage is low. If the firm is worth $500 million, what is the expected agency cost in dollars?






‚úÖ B is correct. Agency loss = 0.04 √ó 500 = $20 million.

Q80.

A firm‚Äôs debt generates a tax benefit of 30 million, while expected distress costs are 40 million. What is the net effect of leverage on firm value?






‚úÖ B is correct. The negative net effect (‚àí10) means distress costs outweigh the tax advantage of debt.

Q81.

A firm owes 1 million to creditors. Its current assets are worth 900,000. A risky strategy offers a 50% chance of increasing asset value to 1.3 million or falling to 300,000. What is the expected firm value under the risky strategy?






‚úÖ C is correct. Expected value = 0.5√ó1.3m + 0.5√ó0.3m = $0.8m. The strategy reduces firm value but may still benefit equity holders.

Q82.

In the same scenario as before, what is the expected payoff to debt holders under the risky strategy (debt = $1 million)?






‚úÖ B is correct. Expected debt payoff = 0.5√ó1,000,000 + 0.5√ó300,000 = $650,000.

Q83.

Using the same data, what is the expected payoff to equity holders if the risky strategy is chosen?






‚úÖ A is correct. If success: equity = 1.3 ‚àí 1.0 = 0.3m; if failure: 0; expected = 0.5√ó0.3 = $150,000.

Q84.

A firm has face-value debt of 1,000,000 due at year-end. Without new investment, its assets will be worth 900,000. A project requires an equity-funded investment of 100,000 now and produces a certain payoff of 150,000 at year-end. If equity holders finance the project, how much of the project‚Äôs gain accrues to debt holders?






‚úÖ D is correct. Without the project, creditors get 900k (short of 1m). With the project, firm value is 900k + 150k = 1,050k, so creditors get their full 1m. The increase in creditor payoff is 100k ‚Äî exactly the first 100k of the project‚Äôs gain.

Q85.

Using the same scenario: debt due = 1,000,000; assets without the project = 900,000; the project requires 100,000 from equity and pays 150,000 for sure. What is the project‚Äôs NPV from the shareholders‚Äô perspective (ignoring discounting)?






‚úÖ B is correct. Equity invests 100k. With the project, equity receives 1,050k ‚àí 1,000k = 50k (vs. 0 without). So NPV to shareholders = 50k ‚àí 100k = ‚àí50k ‚Üí classic debt overhang.

Q86.

A firm‚Äôs unlevered value is 600 million. With 200 million of debt, the PV of tax shields is 30 million, and PV of distress costs is 10 million. What is the levered value of the firm?






‚úÖ C is correct. Levered value = 600 + 30 ‚àí 10 = $620 million.

Q87.

If the PV of tax shields is 50 million and the PV of distress and agency costs together equals 50 million, what is the net benefit of leverage?






‚úÖ A is correct. When tax benefits equal total costs, the optimal leverage is reached‚Äînet gain is zero.

Q88.

A firm expects a tax shield benefit of 20 million if it borrows more, but also expects additional distress costs of 25 million. What is the effect on firm value if it increases debt?






‚úÖ D is correct. Added distress cost outweighs tax benefit ‚Üí net effect = ‚àí5 million.

Q89.

A firm estimates that if bankruptcy occurs next year, it will incur legal and administrative costs of $20 million. The probability of bankruptcy is 30%, and the discount rate is 10%. What is the expected present value of bankruptcy costs?






‚úÖ C is correct. Expected cost = 0.3 √ó 20 = 6; discounted one year at 10% ‚Üí 6 / 1.10 = $5.45 million.
This is the PV of expected bankruptcy losses considered in trade-off theory.

Q90.

A firm‚Äôs unlevered value is 500 million. The present value of tax shields increases by 10 million for each additional 100 million of debt. However, expected distress costs increase quadratically, adding 2 million, 8 million, and 18 million for the first three 100 million increments of debt, respectively. At what level of debt is firm value maximized?






‚úÖ D is correct.
Net gain by level of debt:
- 100m ‚Üí +10 ‚àí 2 = +8
- 200m ‚Üí +20 ‚àí 8 = +12
- 300m ‚Üí +30 ‚àí 18 = +12
Value peaks at $200m debt (first point of maximum gain). Beyond that, costs rise faster than benefits.

Q91.

A firm has a 60% chance of remaining healthy with value 600 million, a 30% chance of moderate distress losing 40 million, and a 10% chance of bankruptcy losing 150 million. What is the expected firm value?






‚úÖ C is correct.
Expected value = 0.6√ó600 + 0.3√ó(600‚àí40) + 0.1√ó(600‚àí150) = 556 million.

Q92.

A firm‚Äôs base value is 400 million. If distress occurs (probability 20%), expected losses are 60 million. What is the expected cost of financial distress as a percentage of firm value?






‚úÖ B is correct. Expected cost = 0.2√ó60 = 12; 12 / 400 = 3%.

Q93.

A firm‚Äôs interest tax shield is worth 30 million. The probability of distress is 25%, and the expected cost of distress is 100 million. What is the net effect of leverage on firm value?






‚úÖ A is correct. Expected distress cost = 0.25√ó100 = 25 ‚Üí Net = 30 ‚àí 25 = +5 million.

Q94.

A company expects a tax benefit of 40 million from higher leverage. However, the probability of financial distress is 15% with expected costs of 300 million. What is the expected net impact on firm value?






‚úÖ D is correct. Expected cost = 0.15√ó300 = 45 ‚Üí Net impact = 40 ‚àí 45 = ‚àí5 million.

Q95.

A firm generates $60 million in free cash flow per year. Managers waste 8% of it on unproductive expenses. If new debt commitments force them to pay out 75% of cash flow to investors, what value is preserved?






‚úÖ C is correct. Value saved = 60√ó0.08√ó0.75 = 3.6 million. Debt can discipline managers by reducing waste.

Q96.

A corporate bond has a face value of $1,000 and a 10% probability of default. In default, investors recover only 60% of the face value. What is the expected value of the bond, ignoring discounting?






‚úÖ C is correct.
Expected payoff = 0.9√ó1,000 + 0.1√ó600 = 900 + 60 = $960.
This reflects the expected market value of risky debt before discounting.

Q97.

Investors believe there is a 50% chance a firm is high-quality (worth 100/share) and 50% chance low-quality (70/share). The firm announces an equity issue, which only low-quality firms choose. What will be the new market price per share?






‚úÖ A is correct.
If only low-quality firms issue, the market updates beliefs ‚Üí price = $70, the value of low-type shares.

Q98.

A firm can issue either debt or equity. High-quality firms (value 120) choose debt, while low-quality ones (value 80) choose equity. If investors observe a debt issue, what is the implied expected firm value?






‚úÖ D is correct.
Choosing debt signals confidence ‚Üí market infers firm is high-type (value $120).

Q99.

A firm owes 80 million in debt and currently holds safe assets worth 75 million. A risky project can increase total assets to 120 million with 50% chance or reduce them to 50 million with 50% chance. What is the expected loss to debt holders if shareholders choose the risky project?






‚úÖ B is correct.
Expected debt payoff = 0.5√ó80 + 0.5√ó50 = 65 ‚Üí vs. 75 from safe assets ‚Üí loss = 10.

Q100.

After several years of high borrowing, a firm‚Äôs management considers repurchasing 100 million of outstanding debt to reduce leverage. Financial analysts estimate that this action would increase total firm value by 15 million because it lowers expected distress costs. However, it would also transfer 20 million of value from shareholders to debt holders, since creditors would gain from the safer balance sheet. According to the leverage ratchet effect, what is the likely decision by shareholders?






‚úÖ A is correct.
Even though the firm‚Äôs total value would rise by 15 million, shareholders personally lose $5 million due to the value transfer to creditors.
They will therefore oppose deleveraging ‚Äî a key implication of the leverage ratchet effect, where equity holders resist reducing leverage even when it increases firm value.

Group 1 of 20
